title: How to extract coordinates and sequence from a fasta file
text: First need updated Rust installation. Go site learn install Rust.

title: How to extract coordinates and sequence from a fasta file

what: Running a tool to extract consensus sequence data
title: How to extract coordinates and sequence from a fasta file
How to extract coordinates and sequence from a fasta file
text: function process fasta file processed using tool samtools consensus. function find regions (subsequences) fasta sequence (, C, T, G) output granges object containing features sequences. invoked follows: toy example use split argument specify many chunks break sequence parallel processing. case doesn’t make sense split sequence chunks example 500-600 bases contig. running real fasta sequence large genome, one want leverage parallel processing. next block show run get_consensus big fasta. One can specify name genome using genome argument. hg38, find takes 1-3 minutes per chromosome using 16 cores intel iMac. recommend splitting fasta contigs 10000 chunks . running full fasta contigs, can check first n contigs full sized fasta using argument test_with_n. Note full fasta read ensure appropriate seqinfo data
code: root<-file.path(.libPaths(), "rustytools/extdata") tfasta=file.path(root, "test.fa") results<-get_consensus(tfasta, cores=1, split=1) results[[1]] ## GRanges object with 7 ranges and 1 metadata column: ##       seqnames    ranges strand | mcols.sequence ##          <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> |    <character> ##   [1]     chr1   238-251      * | ACTGACCTTAAGGT ##   [2]    chr12   102-115      * | ACTGACCTTAAGGT ##   [3]    chr12   595-608      * | ACTGACCTTAAGGT ##   [4]     chr3   317-330      * | ACTGACCTTAAGGT ##   [5]     chr4   168-181      * | ACTGACCTTAAGGT ##   [6]     chr5   171-184      * | ACTGACCTTAAGGT ##   [7]     chr6    97-110      * | ACTGACCTTAAGGT ##   ------- ##   seqinfo: 7 sequences from hg38 genome fasta="abigfasta.fa" #fasta="~/Desktop/GENDX_HLA_Mix1_S1_L001_t1000.fa" results<-get_consensus(fasta, cores=16, split=10000, genome="hg38") fasta="abigfasta.fa" #fasta="~/Desktop/GENDX_HLA_Mix1_S1_L001_t1000.fa" results<-get_consensus(fasta, cores=16, split=10000, genome="hg38", test_with_n = 1)

what: Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
title: Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
text: function reads DNA sequence given FASTA file, splits sequences parallel processing, retrieves consensus sequences split segment.

title: Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
text: fasta character string specifying path FASTA file. splits integer specifying number segments split sequence processing. Default 10,000. cores integer specifying number cores use parallel processing. Default 1. genome character string specifying genome version sequence information. Default "hg38".

title: Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
text: GRanges object containing consensus sequences genomic ranges associated sequence information.

title: Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
text: function reads input FASTA file, splits sequence smaller segments parallel processing, retrieves consensus sequences segment. results combined GRanges object.

title: Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
text: documentation written ChatGPT v4o - OpenAI, conversation author, 6-5-2024.

title: Get Consensus Sequences from a FASTA File — get_consensus
code: if (FALSE) {   # Example usage:   fasta_file <- "path/to/your/file.fasta"   consensus <- get_consensus(fasta_file, splits = 5000, cores = 2, genome = "hg38")   print(consensus) }
